Author: ITM#7678
Content:
I have a quick question.
I see the atomicdex swap happen directly from the wallet.
Let say I Sell LTC for KMD.
The swap is completed but both LTC and KMD transaction broadcasted is unconfirmed.
If a miner decides to create kmd transaction(to his own address), include it in the solved block(nicehash to quickly solve difficulty) but not submit it until the LTC transaction is broadcasted. As soon as that is done he broadcast the solved block. This will allow a double spend to take place?
Am I missing something? I thought is was linked to a cryptocondition or something?

Author: ITM#7678
Content: fine it was not a quick question

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: komodo ecosystem coins use dpowconfs, so they wait for notarizations. other coins can indeed be double spent if enough resources are used, but the economic cost to double spend a single swap makes it a non-economic attack. just dont swap 100 BTC without setting it to wait for enough BTC confirmations

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: this is why we say dont swap large amounts during the beta

Author: ITM#7678
Content: Let say 100KMD, The cost to double spend is less then ~1 KMD.(Since I am solving a block solo with the double spend transaction since the other transaction is not confirmed ). So the dpowconfs don't kick in until 1 confirmation. Now the volumes are low, but when the orderbook is huge, its can slice attack the orderbook in seconds.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the swaps should not be treating the transaction as valid until the dpowconfs shows 2 confirmations

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: which means it is notarized

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: also there is no way you can mine an LTC block for 1 KMD, let alone double spend attack LTC

Author: artem.pikulin#0794
Content:
Also worth to add that only `spending` transactions are left unconfirmed, in more details:
1. Maker sends payment, taker waits for this payment to be confirmed so double spending is prevented here.
2. Taker then sends his payment, maker waits until this payment is confirmed before attempt to spend it.
3. Only then maker is spending taker's payment revealing the secret and taker spends maker's payment.
@ITM Only the `spending` stages are left unconfirmed in this case, the inputs being spent on this stage are hash-timelocked so other side won't be able to spend the transaction until timelock conditions are met (few hours).

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the one issue would be if one of the coins is a low hashrate coin without double spending protection

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it seems for such coins, we need a way for the user to specify the required confirmations for that coin

Author: artem.pikulin#0794
Content: Yes, the problem can occur if even after some number of confirmations the attacker can still double spend the output that was used for swap payment itself rolling back significant amount of blocks.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: maybe we need to allow the user to specify the required confirmations for each transaction. using default value so it doesnt have to be changed if it is acceptable. that would allow the user to specify larger confirmations for larger amounts. or we can automatically scale the required confirmations based on the amounts being swapped

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: probably there can be some algorithm that balances a coins hashrate and economic value of the swap to generate the required confirmations

Author: ITM#7678
Content: @artem.pikulin What if I submit a solved block with double spend transaction before the hash-timelocked transaction is confirm or even properly broadcasted?

Author: artem.pikulin#0794
Content: The MM2 will then abort the swap since the transaction won't ever be confirmed.

Author: ITM#7678
Content: @artem.pikulin When I completed a swap, both KMD and Hush transaction stage on the explorer was unconfirmed. The swap was marked as completed

Author: artem.pikulin#0794
Content: These transactions were spends of swap payments that were confirmed before.

Author: artem.pikulin#0794
Content:
The protocol is as follows:
1. Maker sends payment that protected with hash of secret. We must wait for it to be confirmed.
2. Taker then sends his payment using same hash of secret. We must wait for this to be confirmed.
3. Maker reveals secret to spent the Taker's payment - we don't have to wait for this to be confirmed. The taker won't be able to refund it for long time.
4. Taker uses the secret to spend the payment. Same here, to make a refund attempt Maker needs to wait for long time, but since it passes the transaction will be confirmed.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if a chain is under a constant 51% attack for the entire duration of the timelocks and doing a censorship attack, then it is possible to mess things up. so we need to rely on the expense of such an attack being magnitudes more expensive than would be gained by the swaps

Author: ITM#7678
Content: @artem.pikulin Thanks :). Explained perfectly

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: for BTC the cost of such an attack would be millions of dollars, but for some smaller chain, maybe it isnt such an expensive cost. it is of course safest to be swapping dPoW protected coins, which dont suffer from such attack vectors

Author: ITM#7678
Content: @jl777c So you say we bulletproof in terms of attacker not making a profit?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: practically speaking, yes.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: theoretically, if a user swaps 10BTC worth of some low hashrate coin, then maybe it is possible for an economic attack.

Author: artem.pikulin#0794
Content:
```
maybe we need to allow the user to specify the required confirmations for each transaction. using default value so it doesnt have to be changed if it is acceptable. that would allow the user to specify larger confirmations for larger amounts. or we can automatically scale the required confirmations based on the amounts being swapped
probably there can be some algorithm that balances a coins hashrate and economic value of the swap to generate the required confirmations
```
@jl777c MM2 already has the API to set the required confirmations per coin during runtime (not persistent) - https://github.com/artemii235/developer-docs/blob/mm/docs/basic-docs/atomicdex/atomicdex-api.md#set_required_confirmations. But adding the USD-volume heuristics is also possible, maybe something simple at the start like `if volume > 1000 USD confirmations = confirmations + 1`.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: ok, so the GUI can do a market price vs hashrate based calc for setting confirmations

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: i guess a more practical way is to have 2 confirmation values per coin that we know of and we can manually calculate the > $1000 numconfs, so for small amounts not at risk, it will still be fast, but for anything with significant economic value it uses the slower more secure numconfs. this logic should probably be done by the caller

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: plz make an issue for this

Author: artem.pikulin#0794
Content: https://github.com/KomodoPlatform/atomicDEX-API/issues/547 - done

Author: ITM#7678
Content: with 2 confirmation, the notarized is completed and not possible to reverse. So it can be set. I think hush coin might not be setup correctly?

Author: artem.pikulin#0794
Content: I will recheck it, the `required_confirmations` is set in coins config, will validate that GUI uses proper amount.

Author: ca333#0118
Content: We are not using the increased `required_confirmation` (2) field yet @artem.pikulin - thus requiring only 1 conf.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the final spend wont be confirmed, it is the initial tx that needs to be confirmed

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: for the beta test the required_confirmations are not being used yet

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: but it should be waiting for the initial transactions to be confirmed

Author: ITM#7678
Content: That will explain it, haha. I read ca333 message now

Author: Aron‚ÄúXuanLeeeeee‚ÄúGoldberg#3393
Content: I have the DEX running with the same seed on my Iphone and the Samsung, On Samsung the order is placed and is not visible on the Iphone in open orders, is there a way to change that?

Author: ca333#0118
Content: not yet @Aron‚ÄúXuanLeeeeee‚ÄúGoldberg - since its a pure DEX (100% decentralized and p2p) the swap data is only being stored locally (filestream layer) on the affected nodes/device and where you actually issued the swap. However - you will find the swap transactions in the transaction history of the affected coins detail view (which is blockchain data thus globally available).

Author: Aron‚ÄúXuanLeeeeee‚ÄúGoldberg#3393
Content: ok, that's what i was thinking. thx
